Title: Good but had defective unit
Review Text: I purchased this to replace my "Alienware - Area 51M R2 Laptop - FHD- 300Hz- Intel Core i7 - NVIDIA RTX 2070 SUPER, 32GB RAM" spec gaming laptop. Although it has a i7-10700K desktp CPU in it, it requires two power supplies and the main 360Watt is massive. So I was happy to see not only did this one have one single power supply, but it was smaller than the main power supply of my other laptop. I saw someone say they thought this power supply was massive but compared to the previous two Alienware laptops, this is a great size for the amount of power it provides. Setting this up for the first time out of box took about 45 minutes or so to get all the updates. There were mutiple bios updates from Asus as well. However those were painless as it was pretty much automatic. Other systems I'd have to put it on a USB to install it but the bios updates on this machine were as easy as a windows update. I did a lot of testing with Forza Motorsport, Forza Horizon 5, Ratchet and Clank, and many others. The LCD panel has amazing color accuracy. Sure, you don't get the dark blacks like an OLED or mini-LCD, but it is an excellent screen none-the-less. The ray-tracing worked well. As a casual gamer, I still haven't found the need for it but is definitly cool to see when you can crank it up and still have smooth performance. However, that is where the first issue came in. Although you can run high leel of ray tracing settings, I would get glitches in many games. I would say maybe once every 5 to 10 mintues my character in Ratchet and Clank for example would turn into a series of vertical lines briefly then return to normal. In Forza the exact same effect would happen on some trees in the distance. Not bad enough to return, but definitly not something you'd expect for the cost. I can have lower settings on the 2070 super notebook without those issues. The performance was great, the screen was great, and aside from a few glitches, I was happy. But then I tried to test VR games with a wired link using the thunderbolt ports with the Meta Quest 3. That's when I found any device I connect would only work in USB 2.0 compatiabilty mode. Therefore, it was too slow to play any PC VR games. I tried hooking up my thunderbolt USB-C NAS drive to it, and same thing happened; I could only get about 370mb/sec. When I went into the BIOS, there is a USB test feature. With the Quest 3 connected, it showed it supported USB 3.0 but was operating on USB 2.0. No matter what settings I adjusted in Windows for power, and any USB settings I could find, nothing I connected would operate higher than USB 2.0. When I went to support, they wanted me to send it in for an RMA. That shouldn't happen after less than 24 hours with the system. :) That is the primary reason I returned it. The other thing I didn't like, but not a resason to return it, was the RGB keyboard. There is not really a plain white solution. It has a blue hue to it which doesn't show up in the photo. The WASD area and space bar I think they tried to make unique from the other keys but to me just looks odd. My alienware laptop has a per key RGB and has a clean white if you so choose. I mostly had the RGB off except for the off-white keyboard to see in the dark but even that, if you reboot or do anything, it lights up like a christmas tree with the rainbow effect which would be nice to keep off if you have them off in the settings all the time. Overall for the price, I think it's good. It's about $600 more than the last Alienware laptop I got when it was new. You can order a custom build to this on Dell and is still a few hundred dollars more so I think if you're ok with the keyboard RGB limitations and don't have a defective unit, this laptop has a lot of potential. I think though this may be one of those things where eveyrthing is still new and may be better waiting until a 5080ti type model comes out.

Title: A really solid performer but with some drawbacks
Review Text: I started my journey with this laptop a little week ago. Here are my overall thoughts on this ‚Äúdesktop replacement‚Äù The unboxing is quite the experience. This ‚Äúlaptop‚Äù is a massive beast and you go through a mix of emotions. Heavy and thick and the charging brick reminds you of exactly that, a brick! You instantly realize this is a unit you won‚Äôt be taking to Starbucks for a long writing session but you know this unit is about to blow you socks off when it comes to performance. It‚Äôs plastic but feels incredibly solid. Screen easily opens up and you are greeted with its ginormous Keybed and trackpad with not much flair other than some Rog branding that is tasteful. Once you fire it up you are greeted with a lovely intro and the RGB light show roars to life. The underglow would make bin diesel proud. Setup is the standard windows experience and a few hours of updates and restarts are a must before you can dive in. Once you go through all the updates it‚Äôs finally time to see what this bad boy can do. I‚Äôm a tinkerer and I am a sucker for tuning and running benchmarks. That cinebench 23 score is a sight to see. My 275hx after tuning is scoring 37633 which is just insane for a ‚Äúlaptop‚Äù. Gpu benchmarks left my jaw dropped. I watched 3 1/2 year old precious desktop build get destroyed over and over. This guy is not only shaped like a tank, but it‚Äôs an absolute beast under the hood. Gaming is an absolute dream hands down. This laptop PERFORMS! I instantly knew it was time to upgrade my unit with a fresh 4tb nvme. Opening the back of the laptop was insanely easy. Just slide a simply lever and the backside frees right up greeting you with 2 nvme bays (one is occupied) and upgradable ram slots. The nvme I installed took a bit of time because the built in plastic clip that turns to hold the drive down (no screw needed) and I was honestly scared I was going to snap it because it took a lot of force to turn by hand. After working it back and forth it feels like it probably should. Snug and holds the drive perfectly. Call me crazy but a simple tiny screw holding the drive down would have been easier at least on my unit. Keyboard and trackpad are excellent. This is no MacBook in build quality, but everything functions as it should and the trackpad is usable enough that I wasn‚Äôt instantly searching for my external mouse while navigating windows. Now on to the mid part of this laptop. Its screen has some light bleed in gray scenes but thankfully it‚Äôs not viewable in all content. Its colors are vibrant and really solid for an IPS panel. Just know this screen is definitely not going to win any awards. It‚Äôs perfect for gaming and accurate enough for content creation, but watching movies is going to be a letdown compared to what most of us have in our living rooms. This is a far cry from an OLED or mini LED but it is ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù The speakers are also not going to win any awards. They state it‚Äôs a 4 speaker system but the tweeters under the screen (small slits in the laptop hinge) on the front of the laptop don‚Äôt do much. You mainly hear the downward firing speakers and they are pretty midrange focused. Some dialing in via the Dolby access app solved some of these issues as I found the 500k and 2-4k ranges were boosted far too much and it caused ear fatigue with pretty much any content. Don‚Äôt be expecting much bass below 150hz. Everything is loud enough to hear over the fans when they ramp up, but headphones would definitely be ideal. Battery life is pretty much a joke but I guess it‚Äôs usable in a pinch. 3-4 hours doing light work with the GPU disabled. Maybe an hour in a light game with restricted settings. Short summary- Yes you are paying for the internals and they perform at a high level! Just be aware that there is some drawbacks to a device like this. Yes, it‚Äôs portable in theory, however I don‚Äôt see my unit being taken anywhere other than to a buddy‚Äôs house for a rare gaming session. This isn‚Äôt really travel friendly and the battery life isn‚Äôt great and that charging brick needs to be tethered. The screen and speakers and plastic build all work fine and are usable, but you realize these 3 areas are where the cutbacks happened. All in all if you plan to buy this unit, know what you are getting. This isn‚Äôt really a laptop. It‚Äôs definitely in the desktop replacement class and if you go into this unit understanding that then you will be happy. It‚Äôs a beast of a gaming pc and the specs and performance are enough to make your desktop collect dust. Final thoughts- wait for a sale if you can. Yes you get a lot for the msrp, but there are enough drawbacks that I don‚Äôt feel it‚Äôs worth it at full price when the market is saturated with several respectable competitors.

Title: Outstanding Performer
Review Text: The ASUS ROG Strix G18 gaming laptop is a powerhouse for gaming. The G18 chewed through my favorite games like a hot knife threw butter. Its 3Dmark Time Spy benchmark score was 22,827. The Mobile 5080‚Äôs individual score was 21,815 while the Intel Ultra 9 275HX CPU score was 16,574. I keep reading reviews about how weak the Intel Ultra 9 is for gaming. Not only did this CPU bench well. It games well. Gaming: Mechwarrior Online, or MWO for short is a Direct X 9/11 game that is about 12 years old. It is also the game I play the most and am the most familiar with. There is No DLSS, no Ray Tracing, and no ALLM. Instead, this game is solidly in the class of system destroying, brute force, high horsepower graphics rendering that leverages TXAA anti-aliasing, Post-Processing, and, of course, max fidelity settings. Well, it was back in its day. At 2560x1600, the G18 completely owned MWO. FPS ranged from 130 to 90 with an average of around 100 FPS. In my experience, 130 is where this game tops out. Considering how poorly optimized this game is, 100 to 130 is perfect. Better yet, I was able to maintain this performance connected to my external 34‚Äù 1440 monitor. Next, Diablo IV. This game runs great at medium high settings with DLSS turned on. DLSS is fine when walking around a town. When bossing or in a tough fight, where timing is everything, then DLSS simply gets in the way, and in some cases, will get your character killed. With DLSS on, I was steady around 130 FPS. With DLSS off, the G18 was able to maintain a steady 100 or higher FPS. Graphics settings were set to medium-high with some Ray Tracing on. Finally, Call of Duty Black Ops 6. The first thing I did was run the built-in benchmark/calibration routine. I posted a screenshot so you can see all the numbers. The system scored 150 with DLSS on and 136 with DLSS off. For competitive play, turn DLSS off. It will save you a lot of frustration. Actual game play, the FPS hovered around 100 FPS. This was more than good enough to remain competitive. There was not screen tearing, no lag, and not ghosting on the screen. I actually had some of my best matches on the G18. That is, after I turned off DLSS. With DLSS on, I had some of my worst matches due to the lag or delay in real time, screen rendered information. Overall, less DLSS, my gaming experience was excellent. DLSS has its place. Just not in online competitive gaming. Fan Noise: The G18 has five power profile modes that directly impact system noise. Amory Crate has three pre-configured profiles: Silent, Performance, and Turbo. Amory Crate also has a mode that works directly with Windows Power Plan. Finally, there is the option to build your own power profile. Silent is exactly that. Fans are off. The system will get warm but not hot. Performance mode has a range from quiet to loud depending on system load. Energy consumption increases on the system. This in turn causes more heat which demands the fans run to keep the system cool. While gaming, the fans ramped up to about 80% to 90%. I would recommend a good pair of noise canceling headphones while gaming. Turbo mode is full peak system power, peak heat, and peak leaf blower fan performance. At 100%, the G18 fans are loud. Headphones with good noise isolation is required. The fans running at 100% does a good job of keeping up with the heat. But, the system will still heat up and you will run into CPU throttling. Overall, I feel that the Performance pre-set power profile is an excellent balance between energy consumption, heat management, and performance. Keyboard and RGB lighting: The keyboard is well laid out, comfortable to type and game on, and the keys have a good resistance and return. The only thing I do not like about this keyboard are the translucent Q, W, E, R, A, S, D, F, and space bar keys. In a dark room, or a room with poor lighting, it is nearly impossible to read the silk screened letter on the key cap. I found this challenging in situations where I need to see the key. For example, I use a rare key function in one of my games and want to visually confirm before pressing the key. Not all my games are FPS games. This is not an issue in a well-lit room. The RGB, as a whole, is very well done. The letters, number, and words on the regular key caps are shine through. And each key cap allows light to purposely blead around the edges. The bottom of the G18 has four RGB light strips that can either coordinate with the keyboard RGB or act independent of the keyboard. I kept them on for a few days and then turned them off. The RGB strips are well done, well placed, and cast a lot of light. Asus provides a way to change RGB via some presets. It also provides the ability to turn the lighting off. One place where Asus seems to keep missing the mark is keyboard lighting customization. Aura Creator is a nice to have, assuming it will even detect your keyboard and chassis light bars, but it is insanely difficult to use to any effect. And tying custom profiles to games has always been a hit or miss exercise. Sound: The speakers are clear and good enough for laptop speakers. They won‚Äôt compete with a dedicated headset or dedicated external speakers. They are good enough for YouTube, pod casts, Netflix, internet radio, and other leisurely listening activities. While gaming, the fan noise will overwhelm the speaker audio quality. They are still useful for gaming. However, the competition with the fan noise will eventually force you into a headset. Screen Performance: I think Asus nailed it with the screen. Colors are bright and vibrant. The refresh rate at 240Hz is excellent. I did not notice any ghosting, artifacts, or screen tearing while gaming. Even the fast twitch movements associated with playing CoD6 was clean, fast, and completely immersive. The only thing that would make my experience better is upgrading the laptop‚Äôs screen to an OLED. Or connecting to an external OLED gaming monitor. Upgradability: I upgrade my laptops. Back in the day, laptops had doors and drawers to access hard drives, memory, CD players, and batteries. Today, everything has screws and plastic clamps which are time consuming, difficult to work with, and can often lead to scratches or other unintended damage. Thank you, thank you, thank you Asus for bringing ‚Äúeasy‚Äù back to user-accessible upgrades. The bottom cover has a latch that slides, clicks, and then the bottom cover simply slides off. It could not be any easier. Ram, battery, and SSD slots are easily accessible. The main board is protected by a secondary plastic cover. Final thoughts: This is a beast of a system. The system will get warm regardless of what power mode is selected. Under load, the system fans get loud. Gaming performance is excellent. Daily productivity is excellent. There are power saving features, such as CPU Core Configuration and nVidia Optimus, that will help make this laptop perfect as a workstation and gaming computer replacement. Overall, I am very happy with the G18. I think it is an excellent system.

Title: Multiple buying attempts, all freezing issues
Review Text: I have attempted to purchase 3 of these ROG Strix 18" laptops since February. Every single one of them had freezing issues. I am a system builder, and I know my way around Windows, drivers, updates, SSDs, ect. I know Asus machines very well. My 5 year old gaming Asus ROG machine is still running to this day. I don't know WHAT is going on with these machines, but they are NOT ready for release. The first one I bought had faulty wiring in it, and the backlit keyboard would not work. The second and third ones worked fine for a couple of days, and then started freezing. No Blue Screen of Death. Straight up, freezing. Everything would just lock up. No mouse movements, no keyboard response, nothing. I needed to hold down the power button for a hard reset. Afterward, it would boot up normally, and moments after it would totally freeze again. The LED light next to the charging port would just rapidly flash a while color. I had all the latest Windows Updates, I had all the latest BIOS and drivers from the My Asus app. This happened on 2 machines in the span of 3 days. These are not ready for release, and with the amount of software and licenses I have to assign to my machines and what not, this is unacceptable. At this price point, these things should be 1000% flawless right out of the box. I will not buy another Asus laptop again. This has been by fat the worse computer experience I have ever had. And I am a 25 year system builder. It's a shame, because specs wise these are impressive. Nothing but issues with them. It very well could be BIOS or driver update related. Some of us are trying to run businesses with these machines, and we just don't have time to deal with this garbage.

Title: Performance - by the pound!
Review Text: To reiterate the title - for every ounce of weight of this laptop (omg is it heavy), you will get top rated gaming performance. I guess if you're into weighted blankets, you would want this on your lap while in use. Other than that, some other downsides: -You're going to want to plug this in unless you're gaming for only like an hour at a time -Fan noise can get high -Puts off some heat I loaded up Elder Scrolls Oblivion Remastered from XBox GamePass as I heard it is a machine crippler - I don't think I've ever seen such a beautiful game delivered without any sort of performance hit in the least. The visuals were great, though some may want to try to make the blacks 'blacker'. Absolutely no tearing of any kind. Sound was great for a laptop, though I'd suspect most gamers would be wielding headsets anyway. In the same vain, the touchpad - which worked as expected - is not something I would ever use while gaming - it just seemed to take up more space than needed. I hooked up an XBox game controller via Bluetooth without any issues. Lots of hard drive space to fill up with games. Lots of customization options with the built in Asus apps. If you're into LEDs, there's loads of them. I liked the treatment of them for the AWSD keys which are normally used for movement. The one 'gimmick' I wasn't a huge fan of was the laser light show the laptop generated while sitting idle. I just haven't taken the time to see if that was a thing I could disable. Other than that, the laptop looks great in general. Other highlights: -Ethernet port -Charging cord length was good, though the power brick - again - heavy/big. -Tool-less entry was a little fiddly but once you get it, it is nice, though I don't know what I'd be doing inside this machine anytime soon

Title: What a machine!
Review Text: WOW. I wish I could write this review and just leave it there. I have had other high end gaming laptops in the past but never have I been this blown away by the performance, versatility, look, and feel of one of these machines. First off, the unboxing and packaging. The box that this unit arrived in was just a cool presentation as it lifted the laptop up slightly when opened giving the vibe of premium right out of the gate. Not much included in the box, small instruction and warranty paperwork, the charger, and the laptop itself and you're set. The physical feel of this machine just screams premium. The materials feel nice and at 18" on the screen it's large. I do not intend to do much travelling with this and rather mostly treat it like a desktop that takes up way less space, but if you did want to travel with it, you need a large and sturdy bag. The keyboard is of course RGB backlit and there is even lighting around the bottom to give it that "gamer" look. Booting up, setting up, etc was very quick. It's very fast, but standard windows setup. Immediately moved into downloading some games from the Xbox PC app (I have Gamepass, highly recommend) and getting Steam going. I've tried a few things from indie titles that are not very intense up to the latest releases and some free to play titles. Everything I have tried has run very smoothly and looked very impressive whether I used the built in monitor or hooked up to my normal docking station. Speaking of docking, The setup to connect to my triple monitor, gaming keyboard and mouse, external webcam and mic docking station was absolutely seamless. I've even done a bit of twitch streaming on this system and had no issues. Overall, this unit carries an premium price tag and it delivers. As the PC gaming industry trends more towards portability and ease of use with products like this as well as handheld options like the Steamdeck and upcoming Xbox branded ROG Ally, this premium price point delivers on everything I can think of or could want from a high end gaming laptop. If it's in your budget, this is the one to get.

Title: Laptop gaming beast!
Review Text: This laptop is a beast in the best possible way. Yes, it‚Äôs fairly expensive, but you get a beautiful, high-performance, portable gaming machine. In a nutshell, it runs cool, the fans are not too noisy, the graphics performance is top-notch, and the 18‚Äù monitor is beautiful. It is a little on the heavy side (a bit more than 7lbs) but it‚Äôs perfectly fine to haul to those occasional game nights with friends. At home, I typically use it with a Samsung 49‚Äù Odyssey Neo which it handles perfectly. My old gaming laptop would have some annoying stutter at times during lots of screen movement, but so far, the ASUS has been butter smooth for me. But if you don‚Äôt have or want to mess with an external monitor, the 18‚Äù monitor on the laptop is perfectly fine. It was easy to get set up initially. After the Windows updates were done, I started installing games via Microsoft Xbox. There are some useful ASUS utilities for system performance, graphics, etc. but very little in the way of annoying bloatware like on some computers these days. The 2TB drive gives me plenty of room, so I‚Äôm not worried about having to expand any time soon. You can read all the specs and other details of the system, so I won‚Äôt go into that, but here are some features I like. The RGB lightbar that outlines the underneath side of the laptop is a nice touch. It‚Äôs not something that would have influenced my purchasing decision, but now that I have it, I really like it. The chamfered edges of the laptop are a nice touch, too, and it makes the laptop seem a little sleeker. My favorite feature, though, is the tool-less access to the RAM, SSD, and fans on the back. I don‚Äôt know why every system made from now on would NOT have this kind of simple access. Not that I‚Äôm going to be messing with the RAM and SSD all the time, but it will be nice to be able to make sure the fans are staying clean. I do have cats that like to lay around near the computers, so this is going to be great for keeping the air flow clean. Speaking of the fans and airflow, another nice design feature is the hot air is vented out the back and not to the sides. So many laptops over the years would blow hot air out the side right onto your mouse hand, which I found annoying. With this laptop, the intakes are on the side and the vents are on the rear. One small detail that would have been nice is a power connector that was a 90-degree elbow instead of straight out. The power cord does stick out quite a way on the left side and my only concern is about bumping it or possibly smashing it into something. If it had a 90-degree turn, then it would be a sleeker fit and could route towards the back. Having said that, when I‚Äôm using it with an HDMI cable plugged in, then they‚Äôre both sticking out about the same, so it doesn‚Äôt matter as much. Overall, I‚Äôm super impressed with gaming on this computer. I feel like it‚Äôs top-of-the-line enough that it‚Äôs going to continue running my games for years to come. If this type of machine is within your budget, I think you‚Äôll be very happy with the ASUS ROG Strix G18.

Title: One Month Honest Review
Review Text: Please read this before buying. No proper reviews are out yet, not even on YouTube, so I‚Äôm sharing everything I found, including two big issues that many older models had: backlight bleeding and improper liquid metal application. 1. Display ‚Äì Backlight Bleed? Nope. Some people said this laptop has backlight bleeding issues, but mine didn‚Äôt have any. In fact, none of my friends who bought the same laptop had this issue either. The screen is honestly majestic ‚Äì it‚Äôs huge, super smooth, and bright. No complaints at all. 2. Fan Noise & Thermals ‚Äì Not Bad at All In Performance mode, fans do get a bit loud, but if you wear headphones, you won‚Äôt even notice. Turbo mode makes it louder, but I personally didn‚Äôt see any major FPS gains from it, so I just stick to Performance mode. Surprisingly, the laptop doesn‚Äôt heat up much, even after long gaming sessions. I‚Äôd recommend tilting it slightly using the power brick or a stand to help with airflow underneath. 3. Keyboard & Trackpad ‚Äì Smooth Experience Trackpad is massive ‚Äì feels great to use. Keyboard‚Äôs solid ‚Äì no flex, no rattles, just smooth and responsive typing/gaming. 4. Battery ‚Äì Don‚Äôt Expect Much If you‚Äôre planning to game on battery‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt. I got around 1 to 1.5 hours max while gaming. This laptop is built to be used while plugged in, simple as that. 5. Gaming Performance ‚Äì Rock Solid Every game I tested gave minimum 60-80 FPS on Silent Mode (with Very High to Ultra settings, plus ray tracing and path tracing with dlss set to quality). With Performance Mode, I was getting around 120-130 FPS on the same settings. And yes, I played on native resolution, which is 2.5k. Games I tested: Cyberpunk 2077 Elden Ring God of War (2018) Sekiro Red Dead Redemption 2 Expedition 33 Spider-Man Remastered (2022) I mostly use Silent Mode, which gives me super quiet gameplay and smooth 70 FPS. Honestly, that's more than enough for me. 6. GPU Issues? Initially, Yes ‚Äì But Now Fixed When I first got the laptop, I faced: Screen flickering Black screen after sleep Laptop not waking up properly after heavy gaming After updating all the drivers (especially the GPU ones), everything works perfectly now. Also, Intel GPU drivers aren‚Äôt installed from factory, so make sure you download those manually if you want to switch to iGPU when using battery. 7. Hinges ‚Äì Tight & Solid The hinge feels very sturdy. No wobble or looseness. Feels premium and long-lasting. 8. Liquid Metal Application ‚Äì No Issues for Me One major issue people mentioned with older models was bad liquid metal application, but my unit seems fine. How to check? Run Cinebench R23 and see your CPU score. I ran it on Turbo mode (default settings), and got 35,900. As long as you're getting between 35,000 to 36,000, your liquid metal is probably applied correctly. 9. RGB & Looks ‚Äì Chef‚Äôs Kiss The RGB is just beautiful. Especially the underglow around the bottom chassis ‚Äì looks insane in low light. Feels like a proper ROG beast. 10. Misc Some people recommend undervolting it. But I‚Äôm on stock settings and haven‚Äôt felt the need. So it's up to you. There is no need for overclocking. This thing‚Äôs already powerful enough.

Title: Near Perfect BEAST!!!!
Review Text: This is not the daily commuter, student laptop, or just to Netflix and chill. This is for the hardcore gamer, developer, video editor, or designer (or all of the above). Perfect for those that are tight on space or need to move around. I have been around technology a long time, this is one of the most powerful laptops I have ever used. While not the biggest, it is big compared to most laptops today, but it uses all of that space for good. This full 18" monitor is GORGEOUS, detailed color, bright, just enough bezel to allow your eyes to stay focused on the screen for what ever you are doing. Sturdy and firm casing, you can feel it... this isn't flimsy, doesn't dip or tilt like some other large screen mobile devices. Full sized keyboard with number keypad... Great for a long list of reasons, a lot of laptops get rid of it... it's here and present. My first dislike, is the big oversized touchpad. I am not a fan of touchpads, especially large ones, that then take a lot of space at the bottom of the deck. Being a touch typist, for almost 40 years, it is a little awkward, but not crazy bad. There is just a lot of space.. .Bling it up with stickers :) RJ-45 hard line port, HDMI, and your standard USB assortment of ports. Now for my next negative... Power. The power brick is BIG!!! and heavy. I get it, this big computer needs the power. However, it has a custom power connector to the computer on the side. First would have loved it in the back, as the firm cord, jets out further to the left side, and then with its custom port.. can't readily get a replacement. Seems to be compatible with USB-C charging, but haven't tried pushing it. Thunderbolt ports are going to be really nice, to connect to large monitors. Only tried a single basic connection, worked great, was able to handle my wide screen, with no decline in image performance. It runs Windows out of the box, not going to review Windows, there are thousands of reviews out there. However, I will say that it took about 2 hours to get it all setup, software and hardware updates, and ready to go. Once setup though, here comes the performance. From a gaming point of view, I put it through the most recent Forza, and connected a XBOX controller to play. Racing and graphics was super smooth. The 5080 graphic card, did its job. The computer though didn't even seem like it was pushing itself. Fans were minimal. And the game play was great. no issues at all. From a design point of view, I fired up Adobe Suite, and was able to do my normal Illustrator usage and editing. The big screen was great, and I was able to send it over to my CNC machine and do its work. I don't do a lot of video editing, but did try it out, and full size videos were playing with no hiccups. Rendering some quick edits were fast, very little lag. Uploads to YouTube were quick on my WiFi, that clocked at over 600mps, but I was far from my WiFi7 access point, so this was on WiFi6. Lastly I fired up Visual Studio, to do some sample compiles, and it was great. I typically code on my Mac, but now with this, I will be able to use this Unreal or Unity development, as my Mac is tapping out on that. This is going to be a laptop I can use for a long time. Outstanding piece of equipment, looking forward to more title releases in 2025 and 2026, that can tap into all its power. So to recap: This really gets a 4.25 out of 5: Pros: - Big storage - Big Memory - Big Screen - Big Speed - Big Performance Con's - Custom and Large Power Brick - Big TouchPad and Big "deck" area

Title: Maximum PWNAGE!
Review Text: I am always impressed how Asus keeps raising the bar, over and over and over! I've been a hug Asus fan for over a decade. I use their motherboards (Strix and TUF), video cards, power supplies and even some peripherals. When I need a laptop I've had a few other brands but always gravitate to Asus. Vivobooks are an awesome value for business or school but gaming laptops always push boundaries. I think my first gaming laptop was a G1 and everyone thought it was an AW. Stylish and powerful. What more do you need? I've settled in on Strix and Zephyrus laptops as my workhorse... for both work and play. The 16" are luggable and great for work. Not too heavy or bulky and fit most laptop bags. The 18" variants are more of a desktop replacement but even still, if determined, you can lug them just as easily but you need a spacious bag. The specs on this beast are amazing. Cram the Intel Ultra 9 HX into the case along with 32GB of replaceable DDR5-5600 SODIMM memory, a nVidia GeForce RTX5080 (mobile chip) and yes... finally a 2TB SSD. I was always stymied why manufacturers were stuffing 512GB or if lucky 1TB SSDs in a gaming laptop. Storage is key for a high performance gaming system... a lot of the AAA games take up gobs of space so the 2TB is welcome!!!! Even better is there is a spare NVME M.2 drive slot for an easy way to add to your storage. Back on memory for a second, the growing trend of soldering in at least one stick of RAM onto the motherboard is horrible and Asus doesn't bend to that practice, keeping with replaceable SODIMM sticks. While my previous Zephyrus G16 go scorching hot in the space between the keyboard and screen. That is not the case with this one. Cooling has gotten much better... more heat pipes that move the generated heat easily out of the shell. Pairing the RTX5080 with the 240Hz IPS display at 3ms response time gives you the awe-factor you look for in gaming. The 16:10 aspect ratio at 2560 x 1600 2.5K screen produces amazing clarity and 500 nits of brightness produces bright colors. Along with all the other hardware produces amazing frame rates and of course that depends on what game you are playing. Lots of RGB but glad it doesn't have the annoying lit slash on the lid that last year's Zephyrus had. Turned that off quickly! The keyboard has programmable RGB and I really love the translucent WASD-RF-Space keys. I use the numpad for work so the G18 gets me that with the extra real estate over the G16. Plenty of I/O ports that make connectivity a breeze. Left side you have power (rectangular connector instead of the usual barrel), ethernet, HDMI 2.1, USB-A 3.2, 2 Thunderbolt USB-Cs and headphone jack. On the right there are 2 USB-A 3.2. Wifi-7 provides the fast network connection needed when playing demanding games as long as your wifi system supports the faster speeds. Upgrading this system is a breeze. Gone are the bazillion case screens... okay... maybe 12 that you have to not lose and them grab the guitar picks and pry the bottom off. No sir, now it's a simple slide button on the bottom towards the front and once slid into the unlock position you slide the bottom forward and it's off. I personally don't see the need to upgrade the memory but you can definitely add that second NVME drive. For me... I tossed in a 4TB SSD and slid the bottom back on and the latch snapped to the locked position. Sound from the speakers is okay, could use a bit more bass for my liking but still more than adequate and nothing really to complain about. All in all bravo Asus. A well designed and beastly equipped machine.

Title: This is a gaming monster!
Review Text: To do this review, I had my gamer son assist me in testing the Asus ROG Strix G18 and I wrote the review based on our mutual thoughts on the computer. I would consider myself average to somewhat advanced gamer, but my son is next level and is pretty gifted at gaming (and humbles me quicker than I care to admit). So, this is an honest review from someone that was extremely impressed with this computer and logged a lot of RPG hours in doing this review. When I look for a gaming computer, I want something that can pull it's weight. With tech always getting bigger, better and faster, it often comes down to a few brands and Asus is always a brand to look at first. The Asus ROG Strix G18 is more than just a strong performer, it feels like it was legitimately made with gamers in mind. Like taking feedback from the field and applying those considerations. It incorporates the top hardware, an advanced cooling system, a superior display, and a top-quality build. For me as a gamer/reviewer this is the best gaming computer I personally have had the chance to review. In this review I will focus on the Processor, GPU, cooling system, the display and build quality. I will then tell you why I like it so much. You can then decide if it would be a good option for you.  The heart of the G18 is the Intel Core i9-13980HX. The 24 core (not a typo) processor is among the most powerful processors on the market today. That includes 8 performance cores and 16 efficiency cores. Performance cores handle the demanding tasks and are faster, while the efficiency cores are just that, more efficient and handle the background tasks. For a gamer, this means more than simply high frame rates. It means you can multitask. Specifically, you can game, stream, record and/or browse with superior performance, without slowing your system down. I tested this playing a few different FPS games with the setting placed on high. I had various chrome tabs open, running OBS to stream and listening to some music. No stutters or any sort of delay what so ever, everything was smooth. Everything loaded quickly, background taskers were still responsive and demanding software runs smooth as silk. This kind of CPU performance is beneficial for gamers, as this core power makes sure your games never lag even with other programs running in the background. This computer will handle anything you throw at it.  For any gaming computer, the graphics card is going to maximize the experience, and the NVIDIA GeForce RTX series in the G18 is a powerhouse. These are some of the fastest mobile GPUs available, and they effectively revolutionized the gaming laptop. I tested the G18 with the RTX 4080 model, and the performance was spectacular! Again the FPS's ran smoothly on the ultra settings and it was better than anything else I have owed or tested to date on a laptop. If you prioritize frame rate, this GPU is for you. In the FPS games I tested, I was consistently pushing frame rates well over 200 FPS on the high settings, allowing me to enjoy that crisp 240Hz display. That smoothness can give you a competitive edge over others especially in the fast-moving FPS games where fractions of a second mean a lot. The RTX 40-series also supports something called hardware-accelerated ray tracing. This brings a more realistic look to the shadows, reflections and lighting.  So for a machine running this hard all the time, ASUS apparently understood it needed any equally high performing cooling system. So they utilize a three-fan cooling system with Conductonaut Extreme liquid metal on the CPU. This set up allows the ROG Strix G18 to run cool under the stress load.  I stress-tested the system with long gaming sessions, and I was surprised at how well it held up. Even after several hours of playing Starfield on ultra settings, the chassis remained comfortable to the touch and the system didn‚Äôt throttle performance due to overheating. For gamers, when a system gets too hot, it can affect the performance of your CPU or GPU to protect the hardware, which leads to lag and frame rate drops. With this advanced cooling system, the G18 delivers even performance when you are playing extended gaming sessions. The fans tend to kick in when needed, but they are extremely quiet and of zero distraction. ASUS also allows you to adjust performance and fan profiles using "Armoury Crate," so you can go full send with the fans when you are gaming harder, or you can limit the fan use when you are doing lighter work.  This laptop features a rather large 18" display. The QHD+ (2560x1600) Nebula display with a 240Hz refresh rate. That combo is perfect for anything from competitive gaming to watching a movie. The high resolution provides sharper images as you would expect. What I also learned was that it allows you to use more of your screen than when you compare it to the standard 1080p, Of course the high refresh rate ensures smooth motion while viewing or playing.  The color is another big plus. The panel supports 100% DCI-P3 color, making colors appear to me as more accurate. Blacks and shadows are deep and rich, and the highlights really stand out. When playing competitively, the combo of high frame rates and low latency creates a super responsive experience that can help improve gameplay.  The ROG Strix G18 is a large and heavy laptop, but that is because it is loaded with high end components. It has sharp lines highlighted by lighting. The thing just feels substantial and durable, like you would expect a really gaming machine to be. The keyboard is comfortable with a substantially deep press and the keys light up in a manner that does not affect your visibility of the keys with a nice key response. There are plenty of port options on the G18, with multiple USB-A and USB-C ports, HDMI 2.1, Ethernet, and a full-sized SD card slot. Again, another reason this laptop would be great for gamers and creators. The touchpad is large, and the large chassis leaves enough room for quality speakers that sound excellent.  This is not something that is designed to carry with you all the time, so its not exactly portable. But by far, this is the most portable laptop with the closest to desktop level performance that I have tried to date. But it is a bit heavy in that respect. Personally?
